application-config.description-application-displayed: Application name to be displayed in ADX.

azure-credentials-form.description-choose-authentication-azure-: Choose the type of authentication to Azure services
azure-credentials-form.description-current-user-authentication-: Certain Grafana features (e.g. alerting) may not work as expected. For other known limitations and issues, bug reports, or feedback, please visit <2>the documentation</2>.
azure-credentials-form.description-on-behalf-of-feature-is-in-b: For known limitations and issues, bug report, or feedback, please visit <2>the documentation</2>.

config-editor.description-additional-settings: Additional settings are optional settings that can be configured for more control over your data source. This includes query optimizations, schema settings, tracking configuration, OpenAI configuration, request timeout, and forwarded cookies.
config-editor.tooltip-enable: Enable proxying the datasource connection through the secure socks proxy to a different network. See <2>Configure a datasource connection proxy.</2>
config-editor.tooltip-http-cookies: Grafana proxy deletes forwarded cookies by default. Specify cookies by name that should be forwarded to the data source.

config-help.configuring-azure-explorer-database: Configuring Azure and your Azure Data Explorer Database
config-help.connect-application-database: 2. Connect the AAD Application to a database user
config-help.connect-application-database-description: Navigate to the Azure Data Explorer Web UI via the Azure Portal. The AAD application that you created in step 1 needs to be given viewer access to your Azure Data Explorer database. This is done using the dot command <1>{{dotCommand}}</1>:
config-help.create-an-aad-application-description: Details on how to do create one via the Azure portal or with the Azure CLI can be found <2>here.</2>
config-help.detailed-instructions: Detailed instructions on all three steps can found in <2>in the documentation.</2>
config-help.save-and-test: Use the details from the AAD Service Principle from Step 1 to fill in the field below. Then click the Save & Test button.

connection-config.description-default-cluster-source: The default cluster url for this data source.

database-config.description-configuration-database-schem: Configuration for the database schema including the default database.
database-config.description-use-managed-schema: If enabled, allows tables, functions, and materialized views to be mapped to user friendly names.
database-config.title-error-updating-azure-data-explorer: Error updating Azure Data Explorer schema

editor-help.can-return-any-set-of-columns: Can return any set of columns.
editor-help.escape-multi: {{macro}}($myTemplateVar): $myTemplateVar should be a multi-value template variables that contains illegal characters
editor-help.format-as-time-series-description: Requires exactly one column of Kusto type datetime. (tip: can use Kusto's {{operatorName}} operator to remove columns).
editor-help.format-description: It's possible to modify the format of the data returned by ADX with the "Format as" selector. Here are more details of each option:
editor-help.macros-description: Macros can be used to automatically substitute certain values based on parameters set in Grafana:
editor-help.must-have-timestamp: Must have a datetime column named "{{requiredColumn}}"
editor-help.optional-string-columns: May optionally have one or more string columns. Each string column is considered as a key=value tag pair (where the key is the column name, and the value is the value of the column for each row).
editor-help.requires-one-number-column: Requires at least one value column of a number type. Each value column is considered a metric.
editor-help.return-time-series: Used for queries that return Kusto's "time series" type, such as the {{operatorName}} operator
editor-help.time-from: {{macro}}: {{example}}. The start time of the query
editor-help.time-interval: {{macro}}: {{example}}. Grafana's recommended bin size based on the timespan of the query, in ms
editor-help.time-series-returned: A time series is returned for each value column and unique set of string column values. Each series has name of valueColumnName stringColumnName=columnValue, ... If there are no string columns in the request, the name will just be valueColumnName.
editor-help.time-to: {{macro}}: {{example}}. The end time of the query
editor-help.using-all: If using the All option, then check the Include All Option checkbox and in the Custom all value field type in: {{valueToType}}. If All is chosen -> 1 == 1

open-aieditor.alert-enable-plugin-feature: Install the LLM plugin from the <2>catalog</2>. You can then <5>enable</5> it.
open-aieditor.open-ai-generate-query: Ask OpenAI to generate a KQL query
open-aieditor.title-enable-plugin-feature: You need to enable the LLM plugin to use this feature.

query-config.description-cache-max-age: By default the cache is disabled. If you want to enable the query caching please specify a max timespan for the cache to live.
query-config.description-data-consistency: Query consistency controls how queries and updates are synchronized. Defaults to Strong. For more information see the <2>Azure Data Explorer documentation.</2>
query-config.description-default-editor-mode: This setting dictates which mode the editor will open in. Defaults to Visual.
query-config.description-use-dynamic-caching: By enabling this feature Grafana will dynamically apply cache settings on a per query basis and the default cache max age will be ignored. For time series queries we will use the bin size to widen the time range but also as cache max age.
query-config.description-value-controls-client-query-: This value controls the client query timeout.
query-config.description-various-settings-for-control: Various settings for controlling query behavior.

query-header.body-lose-manual-changes: You will lose manual changes done to the query if you go back to the visual builder.

table-section.tooltip-columns: Select a subset of columns for faster results. Time series requires both time and number values, other columns are rendered as <2>dimensions</2>.

tracking-config.description-send-username-header-to-host: With this feature enabled, Grafana will pass the logged in user's username in the <2>{{userHeader}}</2> header and in the <4>{{clientRequestIdHeader}}</4> header when sending requests to ADX. Can be useful when tracking needs to be done in ADX.

visual-query-editor.title-table-schema-loaded-successfully-w: Table schema loaded successfully but without any columns
